You are here:

SALESFORCE HELP
DOCS
VISUALFORCE B2B COMMERCE
Select Which Locales and Currencies Your Storefront Supports

From CC Admin, select which language and region combinations—known as locales—and which currencies your storefront supports. Select one locale and one currency as the default for your storefront.

REQUIRED EDITIONS AND USER PERMISSIONS
Salesforce CompatibilitySalesforce not available in all orgs) and Lightning Experience for Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions.


B2B Commerce Compatibility

B2B Commerce for Visualforce Winter ’21 (version 4.13)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’20 (version 4.12)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’19 (version 4.11)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’19 (version 4.10)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’18 (version 4.9)


USER PERMISSIONS NEEDED
To access CC Admin and change settings:	Access B2B Commerce for Visualforce Admin Settings permission set

At minimum, a locale specifies an ISO 639-1 language code, such as en or ja. To specify which region the language is for, a locale can also include an ISO 3166-1 Alpha 2 country or region code, such as US or JP.

For example, the language code en by itself probably isn't specific enough for localizing content. But, the full locale codes en_US and en_GB are more specific, and can allow for important regional or dialectical differences that are meaningful to buyers in those regions.

TIP To minimize the data footprint of your localized storefront data, we recommend that you always select the simplest locales available. The region code adds complexity when you create translated storefront content and B2B Commerce for Visualforce determines which language to load. More significantly, the Apex batch jobs that build product index records create records for both generic and specific locales. If your storefront doesn't need the extra specificity, keep your org lean and omit the region code.

To select the locales and currencies that your storefront supports:

Select which languages and regions your storefront supports.
On the CC Admin tab in your org, select your storefront (1).
In the Storefront Settings menu, select Localization (2).
In the Languages for Storefront section (3), select locales from the Available Languages list and move them to the Selected Languages list.
TIP
You can add up to 40 locales. However, the more locales you add, the more complex your org's data size and structure becomes, which can make maintenance—especially when building product index records—more difficult.
To minimize the data footprint of your product index records, we recommend that you always select generic locales for your localized storefront, if possible. For example, select the ja generic locale instead of the ja_JP specific locale.
Click Save (4).
Specify which currencies your storefront supports.
In the Currencies for Storefront section (5), select currencies from the Available Currencies list and move them to the Selected Currencies list.
NOTE Each currency uses the ISO 4217 currency code, such as USD or JPY.
Click Save (6).
Specify which locale and currency is the default for your storefront.
WARNING A default locale and currency are required for the storefront to function correctly.
NOTE If you want to keep en_US as the default locale and USD as the default currency, skip this step.
Scroll to the Localization Settings for Storefront section.
For Default Locale (7), enter the code for one of the locales you added to the Selected Languages list (3).
For Default Currency Code (8), enter the code for one of the currencies you added to the Selected Currencies list (5).
Click Save (9).
NOTE Although you've selected which locales and currencies your storefront supports, your storefront isn't localized yet. Create localized object records and price lists for supported currencies.
TIP For a reference of all locales and currencies that the managed package supports, scroll to the Currency Localization Settings section (10).
SEE ALSO

title: Selecting Locale and Currency for B2B Commerce Storefront
